content:
I suggest you verify the source of the large size. On your question, the profile only reflect the size of its content; there is no default size. To check sizes of files, do this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - if you have IMAP mail, open the imapmail folder to view contents. You should normally recognize everything, such as inbox, inbox.msf, sent, sent.msf, etc. If you see folders you don't recognize or duplicate folders, do a screenshot and post here. - do the same for the Mail folder if you have POP accounts and for the Mail\Local Folders folder.

II any folders have not been compressed, doing that often reduces size.

content:
Oh yes, now I see that you use the cards view! Thanks for the screen shot. I am still a veteran Thunderbird user and have been staying with the table view. So I didn't imagine the blue subject line in new messages (and that's why I had profoundly modified my initial reply which concerned table view). The blue font colour plus the orange rhomb before the subject is the default display (or design) for new messages. As soon as you click on a new message the colour changes to black and font-weight to normal. If you don't click on new messages - leaving them unread - and restart Thunderbird (or change folders) those messages change status and become simple unread messages, identifiable by the green dot and bold black font. (first image) Back to your question to extend the blue highlight of the subject line to other messages: I don't know such a built-in feature. The only feature Thunderbird provides to distinguish or categorise messages are the message tags (important, work, personal, ......) . Yet in cards view those tags are very discreet, unlike tags in table view.

If you're going to use tag colours in cards view and want very apparent colours, you could do this using certain CSS codes in a userChrome.css file to be created in the profile folder. I join a screen shot showing different tagged mails discernable by their tag colours emphasised by my CSS codes
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Se capisco bene tu stai provando ad importare direttamente i file mbox di Eudora in Thunderbird attraverso l'estensione ImportExportToold NG.

In linea teorica il procedimento è corretto e puoi tranquillamente usare anche l'opzione mbox files with sbd (utile solo se avevo sottocartelle in Eudora). Il problema è un altro: Il formato mbox di Eudora è leggermente diverso da quello usato in Thunderbird e probabilmente alcuni flag (come quelle che identificano i messaggi cancellati) non vengono riconosciuti.

Purtroppo non conosco Eudora, ma penso esista come in Thunderbird un comando per compattare l'archivio. Questo comando serve a rimuovere fisicamente le email cancellate che altrimenti restano nel file anche se non vengono più mostrate. Prova a compattare l'archivio e poi a rifare l'importazione.

Una soluzione alternativa potrebbe essere quella di usare una vecchia versione di Thunderbird che aveva una funzione per l'importazione da Eudora -> https://kb.mozillazine.org/Importing_from_Eudora_-_Thunderbird in caso ti interessi posso indicarti dove reperirla e come usarla.

content:
It's not unusual for ISPs to blame the messenger, in this case, Thunderbird. error 550 5.7.1 is an authentication error with multiple possibilities. And Thunderbird is not the problem. This is usually either incorrect settings in thunderibird if emails to everyone are being rejected, but more likely in server settings by ISP if only to specific hosts. Here is some info on that:

Understanding SMTP Error 550 5.7.1 SMTP error 550 5.7.1 indicates that your email was rejected by the recipient's mail server. This typically happens due to security or policy-related issues. The server may see your email as spam, or it may not meet the necessary authentication criteria. Common Causes Authentication Issues 

   SPF, DKIM, DMARC Failures: If your email lacks proper authentication records, it may be flagged as unauthorized.    Misconfigured Mail Server: Incorrect settings can prevent your emails from being delivered.

IP Address Problems 

   Blacklisting: If your sending IP address is on a blacklist, the recipient's server may block your email.    Reputation Issues: A poor reputation for your IP can lead to delivery failures.

Troubleshooting Steps Check Email Configuration 

   Verify SPF, DKIM, and DMARC Records: Ensure these records are correctly set up for your domain.    Inspect Mail Server Settings: Make sure your server is configured to send emails properly.

Check for Blacklisting 

   Use Online Tools: Check if your IP address is listed on any blacklists.

Contact Support 

   Reach Out to Your ISP: If issues persist, contact your Internet Service Provider for assistance.
creator: davidsk

creator: christophleib

content:
You certainly didn't change the default mailbox (also called mbox) storage format, which means that all your messages have been stored in one text file names Inbox. And unfortunately an Inbox files gets bigger and bigger if downloaded messages are not regularly archived or moved to other folders, and it might get corrupt. Thunderbird doesn't make automatic profile backups, it's up to the user to save his data.

Nevertheless verify the size of the INBOX file in Thunderbird's profile folder: go to Help > Troubleshooting Information > Profile Folder > Open Folder (if you are on Mac: Show in Finder). In the profile folder open the ImapMail folder containing then an "imap.xxx.xx" account folder and look up the size of the INBOX file (the one without suffixe). Also ask your email address provider if the have a backup of your account.

content:
For any program 'Full Screen' is Full Screen and Task bar is always not visible.

On Windows 11, I can use 'F11' key to go to full screen and use again to come out of Full Screen.

At the top of each window that is not full screen, there are three icons on top right. The one in the middle is 'maximise' Use that option to 'maximise' the window so it uses all the desktop, but it does not cover the Task Bar.

I presume you have a Thunderbird shortcut icon on desktop. Check it has correct settings.

  • Right click on desktop Thunderbird icon and select 'Properties'
  • In the 'Shortcut' tab
  • Run: ideally set at 'Normal Window' as it gives you options after starting OR if you always want it maximised then select 'Maximised'
  • Click on 'Apply' and click on 'OK'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re :For you setting the shortcut to run in different modes changes anything in start behavior of Thunderbird?

Yes. If Run: 'maximised' Then Thunderbird starts up with a maximised window using all available screen.

If Run: 'minimised' Then Thunderbird will start as 'minimised' and display icon on TaskBar. If I need to then use it, a click on that icon on TaskBar will show the Thunderbird window.

If Run: Normal Window Then Thunderbird will start up in a window of height and width set by me. It might look like it filles the whole screen if that was something previously set up, but the difference is that I can hover over the side edge or top edge, cursor changes to a double head arrow, left click-hold down and then drag the edge to a suitable size. Eg: Window now uses about half the screen size. That means if I maximise using the middle icon, it fills screen and then I can use the same middle icon to 'Restore down' back to normal window size.

content:
I'm using Windows 11 OS and it's up to date. I have to admit I've never used Snap, so I altered settings to check. I've enabled Snap. I hide the Task Bar. I Maximised Thunderbird and it used entire visible screen. I hover over bottom of screen - TaskBar pops up and remains visible providing I continue to hover cursor over TaskBar.

Mmmmmm?! I've been testing things to see if I can get same issue as you.

I disabled snap and tried again. This time I managed to get the error you are talking about and it remains even after enabling snap again.

So I restored down Thunderbird to a normal sized window and moved window so the bottom was at bottom of screen. Interesting - If I hover over bottom of screen where Thunderbird is displaying - no pop up of Task Bar, but if move to where it's not covering bottom edge - pop up of Task Bar appears.

I then selected to open any folder stored on computer - maximised it and hover cursor over bottom of screen and yes I still have the same issue, so I can get the no pop up of Taskbar using any program. I also tested with Edge - same error. This issue is not Thunderbird or Firefox - it's something odd in Windows OS.

Still testing various things.

Re opened the Multitasking in Windows and disabled snap. Closed that window. Not closing it did not seem to get the Taskbar back. So, it's important to change a setting and close window. Restore down windows to hover over bottom of screen and select 'Taskbar Settings' Enabled Taskbar view again and closed. Then open Taskbar Settings and hide the Taskbar

Guess what.... After maximising various windows and testing - in all cases hover over the bottom edge of screen got it to pop up again. Even after enabling snap again.

This problem you are experiencing is not Thunderbird - it's Windows OS. It clearly has a glitch. As I managed to create the problem and remove the problem by only enabling and disabling the Snap feature and the Taskbar hide feature.

The main issue is trying to find out how to force this Windows error to occur with specific steps.

re :Weird that for you setting the shortcut to start Thunderbird minimized works. For me and many others who use Thunderbird do not work and need to use an add-on to do this.

It's Windows that controls the shortcut icon on desktop not Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Do you want to create a new account to access your gmail emails ?

If yes:

Gmail uses Oauth2, so you need to make sure a few things are set up correctly first. Firewall: Access Firewall - it might be the defaulton computer or controlled by an Anti-Virus prgram. Set up Thunderbird program as 'allowed' so nothing gets blocked. Confirm Thunderbird is set up as allowed program.

VPN: Check computer for a VPN. Some Anti-Virus products now offer a VPN and I have come across some peopl who did not realise one had been enabled. Switch off VPN (or create split tunnelling and set it up for Thunderbird to use). Gmail does not like VPN as it atempts to hide your IP address, so gmail decides you might be hacker so it auto blocks access. Confirm VPN is switched off

Localhost: Do you have anything using the localhost? People who manage websites may typically use eg: Apache Xampp. You need to switch of any program using the localhost whilst setting up gmail. You can enable it again afterwards. I had to switch off Apache Xampp. Confirm nothing is using localhost.

In Thunderbird

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Web Content
  • Select 'Accept cookies from sites'
  • Click on 'Exceptions' button
  • Enter this : https://accounts.google.com
  • Click on 'Allow
  • Click on 'Save Changes'

IF you previously had the gmail account and are reinstalling it then you need to clear the passwords

  • Whilst in that area - scroll to Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • If you see any mention of the account you are trying to set up - select the relevant lines and click on 'Remove'
  • Click on Close


Switch off the Account Hub as it's still experimental.

  • Settings > General
  • Account Hub
  • uncheck this checkbox: 'Create accounts in the new Account Hub'

Then create the mail account

  • Menu app > New Account > Email
  • Enter name
  • Enter gmail email address
  • Enter password
  • Select checkbox to remember password.
  • Click on 'Continue'

Thunderbird by default will look for the IMAP server settings. They should be:

  • Server name: imap.gmail.com
  • Port: 993
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: OAuth2
  • Username = full gmail email address
  • Password is the same one you use to access webmail

Outgoing SMTP:

  • Server name: smtp.gmail.com
  • Port: 465
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: OAuth2
  • Username = full gmail email address
  • Password is the same one you use to access webmail
  • Assuming all is ok click on 'Done'

You should then get the gmail pop up browser type window. It will ask you to confirm you really are you and the then askif you want to allow Thunderbird access to server.

Then an OAuth token gets created and stored in the same place as all other passwords.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Passwords can only be created or modified etc via the webmail account for that email address which you access/logon via a browser.

Once the new password has been set up, you then update the stored password in Thunderbird.

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll to Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords
  • click on 'Show Passwords'

Accounts usually have two entries one for incoming and one for outgoing. Username is useful as it usually is the email address. Pop starts with 'mailbox://' Imap starts with 'imap://' Smtp start with 'smtp://' Some accounts use Oauth, so will see a line 'oauth://'

  • Right click on relevant line and select 'Edit Password'
  • Completely clear all contents
  • Carefully type in the correct password

You need to do this for all the relevant line for the account/username

  • click on 'Close'

Exit Thunderbird, allow a few seconds for background processes to complete and then restart Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: I respect your desire for the sig file, but I can not recognize any difference of note. I will offer, instead, a comment: the option in thunderbird to not show sigs on replies is because most users do not want to see the sig repeated multiple times in a conversation. If I were to give a suggestion, it would be to tick to NOT include on responses.
